subject: Real Estate
title: Institutional Investors and the Rental Revolution
description: A tiny lesson with a big payoff: Institutional Investors and the Rental Revolution.

hook.text: BlackRock, Invitation Homes, and pension funds now own hundreds of thousands of single-family rental homes.

buildup.text: After 2008, Wall Street bought foreclosed homes at scale, turning them into a new institutional asset class.

discovery.text: Institutional landlords use algorithms to set rents, automate evictions, and maximize yield across portfolios.

twist.text: In some U.S. cities, institutional buyers purchase 25% of available homes â€” competing directly with first-time buyers.

climax.text: When corporations compete with families for starter homes, the dream of ownership becomes a luxury, not a right.

punchline.text: Wall Street now competes with families for starter homes.

quiz.question: What did institutional investors buy after the 2008 crisis?
